title: 115_s432
content: The "Cerros del Norte Conservation Act" designates the Cerro del Yuta and Rio San Antonio Wilderness Areas. The Act defines terms like "map" and "Secretary" for clarity. The Cerro del Yuta and Rio San Antonio Wilderness Areas in the Rio Grande del Norte National Monument are designated as wilderness areas under the Wilderness Act. The areas are managed by the Bureau of Land Management and encompass approximately 13,420 acres and 8,120 acres respectively. The wilderness areas designated under the Wilderness Act and this Act shall be administered accordingly. Any acquired land within the boundaries of these areas becomes part of the wilderness area and is managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this Act. Grazing of livestock in wilderness areas established before the enactment of this Act shall be administered according to specific guidelines. No protective perimeter or buffer zone is created around the wilderness areas, and activities outside the boundaries shall not be restricted based on visibility or noise within the wilderness area. Congress determines that the San Antonio Wilderness Study Area has been adequately studied for wilderness designation and shall be managed in accordance with the Act. The Secretary is required to file maps and legal descriptions of the wilderness areas with the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. The wilderness areas studied for designation will be managed as part of the National Landscape Conservation System. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on public land in New Mexico is unaffected by this Act. The maps and legal descriptions will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management offices. The Act designates wilderness areas on public land, withdrawing them from certain activities under federal laws. It does not affect treaty rights.
